column6: Text
“Apaṇṇaka Dhammas,” Don't Hold Back pp. 71–81.
Ajahn Ñāniko asks about an alternate translation for "apaṇṇaka dhammas", namely "a safe bet."
[Walking Meditation]().
“The Five Hindrances” from Anthology V1 pp. 35–44.
Should we judge the quality of our meditation only by the time we spend in focused concentration?
[Walking Meditation]().
Ajahn Tate and the bhavaṅga states.
Ajahn Khao meditates all night with no awareness.
“Purpose” by [Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho](teacher:) in Uncommon Wisdom pp. 133-145.
Has anyone had personal experiences of Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho?
You get more of the vibe of Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho by listening to recordings than reading.
Many [recordings of Ajahn Paññavaḍḍho](https://forestdhamma.org/audio/dhamma-of-ajaan-pannavaddho/) are available on [forestdhamma.org](https://forestdhamma.org).
“The Path of Non Contention” by [Ajahn Amaro](teacher:) in Beginning Our Day V1 pp. 215-217.
about understanding metta as radical acceptance.
What is the relationship between truthfulness, the truth of the way things are, and metta?
Bhikkhu Bodhi presents the Ten Perfections in linear order.
[A Study of the the Pāramīs](https://bodhimonastery.org/a-study-of-the-paramis.html) by Bhikkhu Bodhi.
The preception of not-self helps us avoid denying unskillful mind states.
“Awe” from Meditations V6 pp. 47-49.
“Strengthening Mindfulness,” a [Dhamma talk](https://www.dhammatalks.org/audio/evening/2012/120104-strengthening-mindfulness.html) given by [Ajahn Ṭhānissaro](teacher:) on January 4, 2012.
about the translation of saṃvega as fear, terror, or awe.
“Presence” by [Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho](teacher:) in Uncommon Wisdom pp. 147-156.
about the Middle Way being different for different people.
“Where There’s a Will, There’s a Way,” [pp. 12-19](Kamma 1st Ed p. 1) and "Bright Kamma," [pp. 26-31](Kamma 1st Ed p. 23) from [Kamma 1st Ed]().
These readings come from the first edition, which Ajahn Sucitto has substantially corrected and revised. Please use the [second edition](Kamma and the End of Kamma) when possible.
Appreciation for Ajahn Sucitto's detailed descriptions of the maneuverings of the mind.
[Kamma and the End of Kamma]().
Does Ajahn Sucitto describe sati as more a mind quality and sampajañña more a heart quality?
Kamma 1st Ed p. 30.
Ajahn Sucitto suggests cutting out habitual reaction patterns by bringing up the perception of not-self.
[Kamma and the End of Kamma]().
The habitual perceptual patterns condition what we seek out to experience.
[Kamma and the End of Kamma]().
We can see how our body and mnd are in constant flux, but we see others as fixed and solid.
A peaceful sīladhara no longer tells stories in her mind.
“Why Come to a Monastery?” by Ajahn Candasiri in Friends on the Path pp. 13-21.
about desire as natural and the reduction and eventual elimination of desire.
“Why Come to a Monastery?” by Ajahn Candasiri in Friends on the Path pp. 13-21.
The word natural carries positive connotations in English.
Is desire itself the problem or is clinging to and identifying with desire the problem?
Taṇhā is eliminate-able.
about distinguishing between hunger and taṇha at meal time.
Further ++discussion++ about the role of desire in practice. Led by {teachers}.
If you aren't willing to see desire as a dhamma, then you'll never see Dhamma.
“Why Come to a Monastery?” by Ajahn Candasiri in Friends on the Path pp. 13-21.
A practitioner tells Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho that sexual desire is natural. He replies, "So is the Dhamma."
of Ajahn Karuṇadhammo's advice to an anagārika about different approaches to dealing with lust.
“The Beauty of Sila” by [Ajahn Jayasaro](teacher:) in Forest Path pp. 57-68.
I have to brace myself when someone is about to kill a bug.
“Levels of the Breath” from Meditations V5 pp. 47-51.
“The Four Jhanas” from Meditations V5 pp. 52-57.
Are breath energy and awareness the same thing?
“Cultivating Gratitude” by [Ajahn Pasanno](teacher:) in Gratitude p. 53.
During the development of Abhayagiri over the years, has there been a shift in how strictly some practices, activities are followed?
Can we ask for soymilk?
The effects of the gap in seniority between Ajahn Amaro and (then) Tan Karuṇadhammo.
Ajahn Pasanno is lighter and softer now.
The gung-ho early days of Chithurst and Amaravati.
The beginning of sharing circles.
Abhayagiri works because the abbots empower members of the community to be in charge of different aspects of the monastery.
Ajahn Pasanno asks the Saṅgha before accepting invitations.
Ajahn Pasanno is genuinely open to junior members' opinions.
Less admonishment in korwat is needed now at Abhayagiri because momentum has built and you can follow the group.
Ajahn Pasanno consults the group rather than dictating decisions.
Sometimes it's better to be harmonious than to be right.|Ajahn Pasanno
I must hurry, for there they go, and I am their leader.|Sign above a boss's desk
Carrying wood to the Cloth Yurt.
"How is it going? There are a lot of weeds growing on your walking path."
“Being Awareness Itself” from [Don't Take Your Life Personally]().
Ajahn Pasanno delights in Ajahn Sumedho's ability to share Dhamma.
Sumedho will teach you about Nibbāna. I can teach you how to look after your bowl.|Ajahn Chah to young Ajahn Vajiro
Can you recommend a book of koans for inspiration?
Ajahn Chah encourages Ajahn Sumedho to develop the hua tou technique.
[Word of the Buddha]().
Harata Rōshi's response to a question about koans.
“_Khanti_ – Patient Endurance” from The Real Practice p. 20.
about the idea of punishment in the Vinaya.
Where does the story in the reading come from?
“_Khanti_ – Patient Endurance” from The Real Practice p. 20.
Could you give some guidance on when to patiently endure and when to use discernment to deal with something?
A fortune teller reads Ajahn Chah's palm.
“What is the Timeless?,” a [Dhamma talk](https://tisarana.ca/what-is-the-timeless/) by Ajahn Vīradhammo at Tisarana Monastery in 2016.
“The Middle Way of Knowing Mental Formations,” a [Dhamma talk](https://tisarana.ca/the-middle-way-of-knowing-mental-formations/) by Ajahn Vīradhammo at Tisarana Monastery in 2016.
This reading reminds me of a sutta where the Buddha defines "apparent here and now."
Entering a cold river is just saṅkhāra,
“Head and Heart Together” from Head and Heart Together pp. 51-60.
on right view and skillful cause and effect regarding the brahmaviharas.
Did Ajahn Chah emphasize generosity and service more for Westerners than for Thais?
In "[Selves and Not-Selves]()," Ajahn Ṭhānissaro talks about generosity and metta as wisdom practices.
Brief biography of Ajahn Khemadhammo.
“Invincibility” by [Ajahn Khemadhammo](teacher:) from Seeing the Way V2 pp. 11-13.

“The Road Towards the Exit from the Prison of Hatred,” a [Dhamma talk](https://amaravati.org/audio/the-road-towards-the-exit-from-the-prison-of-hatred/) by Ajahn Khemadhammo at 2015 Amaravati Kaṭhina.
How has work with prisoners affected Ajahn Khemadhammo?
Where does Ajahn Khemadhammo live?
Ajahn Khemadhammo creates Buddha groves in prisons.
The inmate leading the Buddhist group was caught selling drugs.
about intoxicants, crime, and prisons.
“Hindrances and their Cessation” from [Anthology V2]() pp. 47-51. An older version is available online in _[Mindfulness: The Path to the Deathless](Path to the Deathless p. 40)_.
“Emptiness and Form” from [Anthology V2]() pp. 53-57. An older version is available online in _[Mindfulness: The Path to the Deathless](Path to the Deathless p. 44)_.
Is Ajahn Sumedho saying that art is always coming from a place of ego?
How do we respond to doubt? ...out of fear, out of worry? How do we try to make things certain and sure? That's what we have to figure out.
about the arising of self even in abstract thought.
about self in creative endeavors.
[Feed the Mice]().
about the role of parents.
Our mothers are our umbilical cord to the universe.|Reverend Heng Sure
“Recollecting Our Goodness” by [Ajahn Amaro](teacher:) in Beginning Our Day V1 pp. 23-26.
At what point does it become unskillful to continue to reflect on one's own good deeds?
In Buddhism, we don't believe in original sin. We believe in original purity.|King Rama IX to a BBC interviewer
Path of Purification p. 104: Forty subjects of meditation.
Western researchers find Tibetans who have been tortured don't suffer post-traumatic stress.
God's finger over the "Smite" button.
The Dalai Lama emphasizes the effect of faith in the law of kamma.
about evaluating the results of practice.
I notice that I have preconceptions about the way I evaluate my practice.
++Response:++ [Ajahn Pasanno](teacher:) distinguishes between investigation and evaluation.
The very pattern, "What will make me good enough?" is suffering.
Aversion towards the nada sound and the importance of having a teacher.
[We Are All Translators]().
[We Are All Translators]() mentions the virtue of using different techniques by different teachers in the practice. Was this part of your decision to choose this reading?
Excerpts from [Rude Awakenings]().
Was your experience (in India) similar to what is described in [Rude Awakenings]()?
How does the opportunity to go on pilgrimage in India come about for monastics?
Ajahn Ñāṇiko, during your time in India, was there a big takeaway from your experience or stories or experiences you would be willing to share?
Going almsround outside Bodh Gaya: "It's rare to be able to give to a samaṇa."
The part of _Where Are You Going?_ where Ajahn Sucitto describes how he felt when his mother died is beautiful.
[Great Patient One](), Chapter 21 "The First Goodbye" and onwards.
I enjoyed the counterpoint between Ajahn Sucitto and Nick Scott in [Rude Awakenings](Rude Awakenings).
“Self” by [Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho](teacher:) in Uncommon Wisdom pp. 235-244.
Ajahn Pasanno, did you have a chance to spend much time with Ajahn Paññavaddho?

Can you say anything about the "voice of dhamma" Ajahn Paññāvaḍḍho describes [in the reading "[Self](Uncommon Wisdom p. 235)"] versus the voice we hear inside our head? is it like the voice of conscience?
“Attammayata” pp. 110-122 in The Island, The Anthology On Nibbana by Ajahn Amaro and Ajahn Pasanno
Sāmaṇera Kondañño asks, "Can you provide guidance on the contemplation of conceiving, and name and form?"
Tan Pesalo asks, "Can you restate Luang Por Dtun's rendering of the Four Noble Truths?"
What does the phrase "beyond good and evil" mean in reference to the mind of an arahant?
“Body” pp. 190-198 in Uncommon Wisdom, Life and Teachings of Ajahn Paññavaddho by Ajahn Dick Silaratano
Questions and discussion about contemplation of body, hair, teeth, nails, skin.
Do you contemplate the body before you contemplate mind?
When you are sick, the body is not happy, so it is not that easy to meditate, right?
Discussion on the Judeo Christian framework in the West and the split between mind and body processes.
“Five Piles of Bricks: the Khandas as Burden and Path” pp. 53 -58 in The Karma of Questions by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro
Tan Kaccāna asks, "Is Ajahn Ṭhānissaro the first voice in a couple thousand years to propose that the khandas may not be a self, or is he drawing from another tradition?"
Could you talk about practicing with intention?
Is volition the same as becoming or an aspect of becoming?
In trying to create separation between self and the khandas, are there other tools that can help around the act of becoming?
“Happiness Forever” pp. 9-10 in Ajahn Sumedho, The Anthology, Vol.3 by Ajahn Sumedho
“Patience” pp. 65-68 in Ajahn Sumedho, The Anthology, Vol.3 by Ajahn Sumedho
“All the Time in the World” pp. 51-52 in Ajahn Sumedho, The Anthology, Vol.3 by Ajahn Sumedho
Why is trying to conquer pain a disaster?
At what point in the Forest Tradition do you use a "warrior strategy" to conquer pain, defilements?

[24:01] Tan Kaccāna asks, " In working with the breath, when I try to spread well-being throughout the body, it seems to diminish. how do I discern whether to maintain this feeling or go back to the more intense feeling?"
[26:27] Does insight arise from deeper concentration or can it also arise from different things?
[29:02] Comments about samadhi and continuity of practice.
“Reflecting on Beauty and Disappointment” a talk by Ajahn Vīradhammo at Berkeley Buddhist Monastery on November 3, 2015.
“The One Who Knows” an unpublished talk by Ajahn Kalyāno at Bodhiyana Monastery, Melbourne Australia on October 2012 (with permission).
“Alone Together” pp. 151-159 in Unexpected Freedom by Ajahn Munindo
Comments regarding spiritual friends and being a householder.
Tan Kaccāna asks, "How much reading is appropriate?"
Discussion about loneliness, aloneness, and solitude in the practice.
“Identity” pp. 67-76 in Ajahn Sumedho, The Anthology, Vol.4 by Ajahn Sumedho
Can I respond to my thoughts in ways that I think are useful?
“Memory” pp.199-210 in Uncommon Wisdom, Life and Teachings of Ajahn Paññavaddho by Ajahn Dick Silaratano
Comment about the meaning of sanna as memory.
“Why am I Talking?” pp. 92-94 in Beginning Our Day, Vol.2 by Ajahn Amaro
recollection of teaching on mindfulness to develop right speech.
“The Wisdom of the Ego” pp. 44-49 in Heart and Head Together by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro
Comments on skillful happiness and the need for patient endurance.
Ajahn Jotipālo asks, "Regarding internal happiness, is part of our problem that we don't have enough means to access it?"
Discussion about the importance of spiritual friendship.

Discussion about psychotherapy models, attachment, and self.
“The Deathless Drum” excerpts from Chapter 9 in Rude Awakenings by Ajahn Sucitto
Ajahn Pasanno recollects time in India.
Comments about decline of Buddhism in India; Buddhism not having a central physical location.
“Feeling” pp. 211-220 in Uncommon Wisdom, Life and Teachings of Ajahn Paññavaddho by Ajahn Dick Silaratano
Comments regarding mindfulness, the brahmaviharas, and radical acceptance
Tan Pesalo asks, "What is the balance between sorting out feelings internally and expressing feelings externally, not repressing them?"
“Citta” pp 246-256 in Uncommon Wisdom, Life and Teachings of Ajahn Paññavaddho by Ajahn Dick Silaratano
The way Ajahn Paññavaddho describes Citta sounds like a soul? Can you discuss?
Discussion about Thai Forest Masters describing Nibbana.
If, in meditation, one sees thought at the point it arises, is it the sense consciousness that sees that or the pure Citta?
How was "Atta" defined in the Buddha's time?
“The Skill of Restraint” pp. 83 in Meditations, Vol.4 by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro
“Two Analogies” pp. 32-36 in The Paradox of Becoming by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro

Would you speak on skillful and unskillful ways to approach restraint?
Ajahn Jotipālo asks, "Regarding the Honeyball Sutta, is withdrawal of external contact, e.g. eye contact, enough?"
“Trusting in Wholesome Intentions” pp. 215-221 in Ajahn Sumedho,The Anthology, Vol.5 by Ajahn Sumedho
How much did you have to adapt Ajahn Chah's training for your own practice?
Did Ajahn Chah have a common statement about his own core practice?
Reflections about Ajahn Sumedho and Ajahn Chah.
Ajahn Pasanno recalls early years in Thailand.
“Realizing Cessation” pp. 44-53 in Small Boat, Great Mountain by Ajahn Amaro
Did Ajahn Sumedho have a period when he was more influenced by Zen teachings?
“Awareness: Nameless and Stopped” a blog post by Ajahn Sucitto
Does Abhayagiri have its own Korwat?
Discussion about bowl washing; monastic training as living by example.
Attending to Name and Form; how does one understand name and form ceasing, or name and form not arising?
Is there a precise definition of the saṅkhāra of delusion?
“Rebirth” pp. 163-165 and pp. 120-124 in Uncommon Wisdom, Life and Teachings of Ajahn Paññavaddho by Ajahn Dick Silaratano
Beth asks, "Did you go to his cremation?"
“Relating to Hindrances” pp. 27-32 in Working with the Five Hindrances by Ajahn Tiradhammo
Ajahn Ñāniko asks, "Where does the expression "sad is mad" come from?"
Is sleepiness not dullness? Is there a separation?
“Daughters and Sons” pp. 6-26 by Ajahn Jayasaro

Question and discussion about how monastics and lay practitioners can navigate visiting their relatives who are not Buddhists.
Tan Kaccāna asks, "How can I change my motivation around trying to get my Buddhist parents to adopt the correct Right View?"
“The Gate of Relativity” in Kalyāṇa, Dhamma Talks from Ajahn Sucitto
Question and discussion about neutral feeling and awareness.
In what ways is neutral feeling delusion?
Tan Pesalo asks, "What does a delusion type of person look like?"
“Santutthi and the Meaning of Contentment” pp. 2-4 in Beginning Our Day, Vol.1 by Ajahn Amaro
Ajahn Jotipālo asks, "What are your thoughts about developing wholesome qualities when there are so many things that mask them?"
Discussion of contentment as necessary for concentration; for interest in the breath.
“Prayer and Devotion” pp. 124 -135 in Unexpected Freedom by Ajahn Munindo

Discussion of beneficial effects of prayer even without an external entity to which it is directed.
“The Treasure House” excerpts from chapter 10 in Rude Awakenings by Ajahn Sucitto
Ajahn Pasanno describes his time in India with Ajahn Jayasaro.
“Basic Premises” pp. 7-16 in With Each and Every Breath by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro

Sāmaṇera Kondañño asks about the differences between expansive knowing, concentration, and divided knowing or awareness; difference between viññāṇa and paññā.
“The First Noble Truth” pp. 14-28 in The Four Noble Truths by Ajahn Sumedho
Sāmaṇera Jāgaro asks, "What does "sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā" mean in relation to the first Noble Truth?"
“Recollection of Hell” pp. 205-209 in Meditations, Vol.6 by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro
“Pissing on Palaces” pp. 241-246 in Meditations, Vol.6 by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro
“Ancient Teachings on Non Abiding” pp. 18-29 in Small Boat Great Mountain by Ajahn Amaro
“Is the Sound Annoying You?” pp. 66-72 in Small Boat Great Mountain by Ajahn Amaro

Tan Pesalo asks, "What is the difference between upadhi viveka and citta viveka?"
What is the value of assigning a monk to do chores rather than sitting practice?
Discussion about keeping the continuity of practice within engagement and daily life.
What is right effort? What is the right level, kind of effort so that mindfulness comes more easily?
“The Second Noble Truth” pp. 29-37 in The Four Noble Truths by Ajahn Sumedho
Tan Kaccāna asks a question about views on whether the cause of suffering is desire or clinging to desire.
“Sense the Sacred” pp.127-137 in Don’t Take Your Life Personally by Ajahn Sumedho
“Working with Perception” in The Insight Journal, Winter 2009 Barre Center for Buddhist Studies by Ajahn Sucitto
What is a good question to pose to yourself to investigate perception?
Discussion about perception and name and form.
Is there a way to stabilize the perception of impermanence?
Discussion of sanna and paññā.
“Parting Words” a talk by Ajahn Vīradhammo at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery on July 1, 2011
